title: How to Decorate Your Room with Magazine Pictures

steps.headline: Gather at least 3 magazines that you like.
steps.description: Most modern magazines feature colorful, beautiful photographs and advertisements, so it’s hard to go wrong. If you’re having a hard time choosing, think about topics that you like. There’s pretty much a magazine for every interest. If you’re into fashion, look at Elle, Harper’s BAZAAR, Vogue, and Marie Claire. Sports Illustrated and ESPN The Magazine are pretty popular sports magazines, but there are also more specific ones for each sport. National Geographic Traveler, Geographical, and Wanderlust are all good options for travel magazines, if you’re looking for landscape photos.

steps.headline: Rip out whole pages with photos that you like.
steps.description: Gently rip out the pages to get a clean tear. If you don’t feel comfortable doing this, you can use scissors to cut them out. The covers often are the most eye-grabbing, but you can find several whole-page spreads and nice photos inside the magazine as well.

steps.headline: Decide if you want to do a full-wall collage or a smaller collage.
steps.description: Full-wall collages are essentially magazine wallpaper, and they can really add color and interest to a space. It’s more typical to do this on one wall (as opposed to all the walls) in a room. In contrast, small collages feature individual cut-out images arranged and pasted on a piece of posterboard.

steps.headline: Lay out your photos to see how they’ll look on the wall.
steps.description:
If you’re doing a full-wall collage, you will want to lay out your images on the floor to get a sense of what they will look like. If you’re doing a smaller collage, arrange them on the piece of posterboard that you want to use. There’s no hard-and-fast rule as to how you should arrange them — just play with placements and color schemes to see what appeals to your eye
When arranging full-page photos, they don’t have to be perfectly aligned, but try to avoid a huge amount of overlap.

steps.headline: Attach your cut-out photos to posterboard using a glue stick.
steps.description: If you’re doing a small collage, spread a thin, even layer of glue over the back of your images and paste them down, starting with the images in the back-most layer of the collage. Slowly work your way up to the images on the top-most layer of the collage. Be careful not to apply the glue-stick too forcefully, as this can lead to ripping of thin magazine paper. Avoid using liquid glues. They can easily warp and stain magazine paper.

steps.headline: Stick the pictures or posterboard to the wall using a paint-safe adhesive.
steps.description: There are several adhesives that may take paint off of the wall, but there are many safe adhesives to choose from. Double-sided removable tape is made specifically for hanging posters. Scotch Magic Tape is thin, and will easily detach from the wall when you want to remove it. Blue removable putty is usually better for thicker paper, but it will work in a pinch. Tear off small portions of it and stick it to the corners of the photos before pressing it onto the wall. Command Strips are heavier and great for hanging up posterboard.

steps.headline: Place your images in frames and arrange the frames on the wall.
steps.description: Alternatively, you can frame your magazine images and group them together in an aesthetically-pleasing way on the wall. This can bring a more classy, finished feel to the collage. Be sure to properly hang your frames using the right tools.

steps.headline: Pick a quote that you want featured on your wall.
steps.description: If you’re having trouble thinking of one, think about choosing a quote from your favorite book or movie. Just be aware that longer quotes are going to extend the time required for this project. BrainyQuote.com is a handy quote search engine that can be a great starting point. Consider choosing a quote that represents a personal goal or mantra that you are trying to live by — for example, “be positive,” or “carpe diem.” This way, you will be reminded of it every time that you look at your wall.

steps.headline: Type out the quote In a word-processing program.
steps.description: Pick a font that is easy to read and will be fairly easy to paste images on, so avoid script or anything with ornate lettering. The color of the font does not matter. Keep in mind that typing the quote in all capital letters will give you more room to paste your images on the letters. Common word-processing programs are Microsoft Word or Google Docs.

steps.headline: Enlarge the text so each letter takes up a full page and print.
steps.description: Increase the font size until only one letter can fit per page. Then, print out your word document. You should, at this point, have several pages with large letters on them.

steps.headline: Cut out the letters using scissors.
steps.description: Carefully cut around the edges of the letters. Try to make the cuts as close and as smooth as possible, as you will be using these letters for stencils later in the process. If there are letters with white space in the middle of them, like O or P, removing the white space is optional. Choosing to leave the white space when tracing can give you more freedom when choosing images from the magazine later.

steps.headline: Tear out magazine pages with interesting patterns or photos.
steps.description: Rip out anything that catches your eye, or that you think would make an interesting background for a letter. This can range from visual patterns to photographs of people to landscape pictures.

steps.headline: Outline your letters on the magazine photos with a permanent marker.
steps.description: Using your printed letters as stencils, trace the outlines of your letters onto the magazine paper with the images that you have chosen. Do your best to make your outlines as precise and close to the lettering as possible. You may want to use a silver or lighter-colored permanent marker for this, as it can be hard to completely cut around the marks from black permanent markers.

steps.headline: Cut out the traced letters from the images.
steps.description: Now, use scissors or an X-ACTO knife to cut out the letters that you traced onto the magazine paper. For a cleaner look, cut inside of the outline so you avoid seeing marker lines on the outlines of your letters. Alternatively, if you like the marker-outlines look, you can cut outside of the lines, leaving a small amount of space beyond the line. This can really emphasize the homemade look of your project.

steps.headline: Attach the magazine letters to the wall using a wall-safe adhesive.
steps.description: Removable poster-tape or Scotch Magic Tape can work great here, especially because these letters will be very light. Consider affixing your quote above a bed headboard, or around a mirror in your bedroom. You can definitely be creative in your placement of the quote.
